What's the best start word for 6 letter wordle?

COARSE? C is the second most common starting letter, and the A is common in the third and fourth positions, and SE at the end is common.
SATIRE? Many words start with S and end in E, and have a vowel in the third and fourth position. E, A, R, I, T, and S are the most common
Any others?

Most of the time you will get a word with two vowels and three consonants or thereabouts. So the vowels are two found from a possible five, while the consonants are three chosen from a possible 20.

I made a small project a while ago that only looked at how many answers a particular opening word eliminated on average, and sorted the ~13,000 possible guesses based on that. My list was pretty similar, the top 4 guesses are the same just a different order (ROATE, RAISE, RAILE, SOARE). But like he said, that only accounts for the first guess being as good as possible by itself, rather than to be used to best solve the game in the least number of guesses. That's why guesses such as AUDIO and ADIEU aren't as good as people think they are, because unless you're solving it in 2 guesses you're gonna have to repeat some vowels early on in the game.

The point about overfitting it important, too, not just because Wordle could change its word list, but because Lingo (the gameshow on which Wordle is based) would have an entirely different word list, and any other clones of Lingo/Wordle would have different lists, too. Also the bonus rounds in Lingo have more than five letters, which this algorithm would totally fail at.

The point is if you train it to play Wordle, it won't be able to play a game with the same rules, it can only play Worden.

Thanks for this. I’m not sure but it seems to me this is basically telling a computer how start. But in reality a human uses different tactics. For example if there’s a letter T and no more vowels, I know there are only a few consonants that can be next to the letter T in most words. So is it TH? TR?  If there’s a vowel in the second letter position and the letter E in the 4th position, chances are very good that the 5th letter will be a D, R or S. Including those letters earlier can save steps.

I would also like to say, as someone who has also written a relatively advanced Wordle solver and also been accused of missing the point of the game . . . that for some of us, the analysis IS the game. An unaided human might play the game using heuristics and intuition about the English language, and that certainly represents a kind of understanding of the problem. However, leveraging the tools of information theory, graph traversal, tree search, probability, etc. to extract structure also represents a kind of understanding. It is a different way to play the game and leads to a different sort of appreciation. I think it would be a mistake to assign one approach or the other a value judgement, or to accuse one of "ruining" the other.

I find your channel always interesting, enjoyable, and thought provoking. But I think there's something wrong.
I don't know much about game theory, and I don't know how well game theory fits the Wordle challenge - probably it's not a natural but a forcible fit, workable but not ideal. But one idea from game theory that I think works here is the idea of a mixed strategy.
Essentially, you've established a correspondence between a 'vocabulary' or 'corpus' (let's call it) and a starting word: given a set of possible target words what one word provides the maximum reduction in uncertainty for future guesses. You then label this as the best starting word.
Now if the 'corpus' were different - say, words with no double letters, or words without 'e' - then your method might choose a different word that would reduce uncertainty.
The catch is that whether you 'know' what corpus the target word comes from. You've set up the problem thinking that you DO know the corpus, but the Bayesian in me suspects that you do not.
So maybe you have a 50% certainty that the word has an 'e' in it, and there's 50% chance that it has no 'e'. In the first case, perhaps the initial guess that provides the maximum reduction in uncertainty is WORD1 and in the other case the initial guess is WORD2, and WORD1 <> WORD2. Wouldn't the best strategy be then a mixed strategy: flip a fair coin and use WORD1 if and only if heads comes up, and WORD2 otherwise? I think so. Not sure, though. Maybe if the reduction in uncertainty for the two starting words is very different.
Effectively this is why even the best Wordle players vary their initial words: they are reflecting their uncertainty in the collection of words.
Now yes there IS an established corpus of answers, but it's very very large. One can partition it into two sets a much larger number of ways. Does this matter? I don't see how. I think that acting as if the corpus were unknown is a prudent way of acting.
I also think that it matter how one defines success: is it the probability that you'll guess the right answer in six guesses? Or is the "objective" is to minimize the number of guesses? There are probably five words that incorporate 25 different letters, so that by putting in those five words you might discover all the letters in the target word, so with some skill at anagramming, you can determine the target with a high degree of certainty. This would maximize the likelihood of getting the target by the sixth guess, but it feels wrong to me. The objective of WORDLE seems to be closer to the second - minimize the number of guesses - but it's probably somewhere between these two objectives, and my reaction to the presence of uncertainty is to pursue a mixed strategy.

Anyway, I admire the work you do, and look forward to your future productions. Thanks in advance.

With a little more practice than before, and after watching the earlier video, I have a much better appreciation of the way in which the wordle bot works. But I wonder if there is yet another 'bit' of information that could be used in the analysis. Not all letters have the same "value" - there is a need to identify the vowels and simultaneously to identify the consonants.

I tend to pick my first word at random (I even started one game with "FUZZY" just because I felt like it, and with no apparent reduction in my ability to solve the puzzle within 4 guesses) with the caveat that I generally want a word that has two different "vowels" (A, E, I, O, U, and Y). If I use a word that has three vowels, I will be wasting a letter in future guesses because I will need to use a vowel that I already know is or is not in the solution. If I choose a word with one vowel, the result divides the vowels into two categories - the vowel I guessed is either in or not in the solution, and I know nothing at all about the remaining vowels. An alternative strategy that I have not tried (tomorrow is another day) would be to choose "ADIEU" as my first guess to minimize the uncertainty about the vowels and then use subsequent guesses to look for the correct position of the known vowels.

At the same time I am working on the vowels, I use my remaining guesses to identify consonants. I tend to divide consonants into three rough groups - the common (e.g., R, T, P, S, D, L, N, M), the uncommon (Q, W, J, Z, X, V), and everything else (F, G, H, K, C, B) consonants (informed by vague recollections of the values of the letters in Scrabble). I generally focus on the common and intermediate consonants in my second guess, trying the maximize the number of different consonants I can use in the first two guesses.

There are yet other categories that could be considered. It is very unlikely to encounter a word with a "Q" that doesn't also include a "U", and there are some combinations of letters that are very unlikely to occur in a five letter word ("W" and "X" or "W" and "Z", for example).

This is all notional; I have not done any calculation to see if my approach is efficient, and it would be interesting to see if these concepts have any actual utility.

I appreciate the analysis from an information theory standpoint. There might be an interesting point to be made from the best theoretical analysis to develop a solid strategy in wordle. I believe the best theory would be one from a linguistic standpoint.

For example, we know that (in the English language) nearly every word needs a vowel. So early words that eliminate all the vowels are handy - adieu, ouija, etc. For a 5 letter word, you can probably expect 2 vowels, frequently 1 vowel, but rarely 3 or more. Clear follow up words that eliminate any remaining vowels (if necessary) as well as picking up on letters that commonly form consonant blends are useful. In a 5 letter word with 1-2 vowels there will have to be a consonant blend or two. S, R, L, H, and rarely w are our letters commonly used to form consonant blends.

You might decide that it's unnecessary to eliminate all the vowels in the first 2 guesses, and that it's better to eliminate the more common vowels and letters used in consonant blends on the first guess instead. Therefore, SHARE is actually a very useful word as a first guess. It picks up 3 of the most common letters used in consonant blends, as well as the common A vowel - and perhaps the most useful vowel, E.

Of course, a curve ball can always come your way. You need to remember the use of double letters, and there are the consonant digraphs that are tricky such as KN, NG, or MB. A linguistic analysis may not get you the absolute best starting word, but it can give you the tools needed to beat the game better. It would be interesting to see whether information theory or linguistic knowledge gets better results overall.

All y'all are kinda missing the full point of the second analysis.

You shouldn't just have an opening two words you use every time, you use an opening word and then based on the results you get you need to determine the best second word to guess.

I will add that thinking about how you would make such an algorithm SHOULD change how you play the game. For example, most people, when they first play the game, incorporate known letters in subsequent answers. This may be the optimal strategy when you get a lot of information from your first guess, but in many cases, you can gain more information by checking a fresh set of letters.

For example, if your first guess is "HINKY" and the "INKY" show as green, it would be difficult to test for B, D, F, J, K, L, O, P, R, S, W, and Z. And the human brain would think Binky, Dinky, Kinky, and Pinky are more likely than Finky, Jinky, Linky, Oinky, Rinky, Sinky, Winky, and Zinky. So a human would be prone to guess one of the (perceived) likelier answers and hope for a win on the second or third guess. If you try to come up with a word like LORDS to gain more information on your second guess, you might get more information and you might not, but you're guaranteed to not get the correct answer on your second guess.

If, on the other hand, your first guess is "STARE" and only the A shows as yellow (or green), you should use five new letters to gain more information. If you continue to guess where the A is, you might get more information about the A, but you only get 4 new letters to choose. If you choose 5 new letters, you increase your chances of gaining new information by 25%.

Great video.
One thing that wasn't mentioned and I feel is important is that letters can be divided into two distinct functional classes, the vowels and the consonants.
Each of those classes has a different level of information as far as guessing.
There is also the elimination process, it's not only guessing the letters in the word , but also eliminating the maximum number of letters.
My strategy is to have two opening guesses that take this into account.
The two words would essentially eliminate all the vowels that aren't in the word. This drastically reduces the sample space. The bonus is that it doesn't rely on a relatively small list of possible words. It then comes down to being not so much a guessing game and become much more of a deductive game in the later phases.

on the final note, human intuition relies on the neuroplasticity of networks of both sensory-processing and intention-executing neurons in the brain that both contain the same ability to picture, imagine, “weigh”, and evaluate distributions of information entropy.

As an example, the way babies stare at new faces (and go back and forth between new and old faces in view) is the brain learning what’s rare, different, or informative about the set of faces it has seen and can remember.

I think two limitations to the algorithm used to play the game compared to how a human plays the game better are (a) we have experienced millions of encounters with words in the English language and tons of encounters with personalities/behaviors, and there are both language patterns like the location of a letter within a word (excluding what could or can’t come before/after it) and couplets/triplets of linked-letters, etc. as well as human-behavior patterns like what we expect someone to have chosen as the word, given their other choices from past games and what we imagine their personality to be like and therefore think they’d want the word to be, and our minds can apply a lot of that information based on our unique past experiences; and (b) it’s totally cheating to access the source code as a human playing this game, so our learning-model starts differently - we start with no knowledge about the rules or assumptions of the likelihood of choices and we are conscious of our ability to “expend” attempts through an exploration-strategy in order to learn a better strategy to adopt - the trade offs of trial and error

And those two parts make games really fun and also great mental sharpening tools. Part of what’s great and enduring about card games is a sorted deck of cards should have a uniform likelihood of each card being drawn, and while the rules of the game make some sets of cards rare and valuable, we don’t ever know the strategies and hands of our opponents until we begin to play, and even then we can never be so sure things aren’t changing at every moment. That’s when we have to choose what to believe, in order to decide how to play the game, and that’s a lot of fun and emotion (think family uno nights and poker). Humans are kick Ass at statistics, and concepts like “Entropy” are just really really powerful ways of expressing our introspection about our learning strategies and the statistics and likelihoods of our environments. But nothing changes the unknowable nature of competitive gameplay strategies, and the way models have to choose what assumptions to believe is similar to the way we might choose what to believe when deciding our strategies in a game of cards

I watched this video a month ago when it was released. But it has been bugging me. Since the beginning of Wordle when I did my own calculations I've used 'aeros' followed by 'clint'. I am for sure not one that should question Grant and agree that a computer-based strategy his videos are great. But my (a humans) use of the start words is to give me the best possible chance at revealing as many letters hits as possible and then a human takes over without any additional tools. For this, I calculate the most likely chance of letters hitting. This is my list of letters (most probable to least) [e, a, r, o, t, l, i, s, n, c, u, y, d, h, p, m, g, b, f, k, w, v, z, x, r, j]. Now there are one-word solutions that can give better coverage of the initial letters but that significantly reduces your second-word choices so my calculation balances letters to yield two words that cover the 10 most likely letters. I think humans (or at least my brain) are already biased toward more common words. Anyway, that is my strategy in a nutshell. I guess what I am saying is bisecting the space does not seem as valuable (to me) as seeing as many letters as possible that are in the word.

It is really and exercise where any 5 letter word can probably be solved in 4 to 6 tries.  You could use your first 3 words to  figure out letters, or just the first two words.  Just pick two words that utilize all the vowels, a, e, i, o, and u, then any of the most common continents of r, s, t, m, n, L, d.  You can typically plug in b, c, g ,h or p to see if they make the daily guess word.  It can also help that if you don't make a legal word, it won't take.  So technically every possible 5 letter word can be discovered in 4 to 6 tries.  Some letter combinations you don't have yet can cause a failure if you got more options than chances.  uncommon letters being used could throw you off as well.  Proxy was one word I did fail since x and y are not as common.  Y can be common but both together is something the mentality may not get drawn towards.

I'm pretty new at Wordle, and so far have had success with using my first three guesses to identify as many of the letters as possible without repeats.  Choosing words that don't repeat the vowels of a previous guess (unless absolutely necessary) generally gives me a sampling of about half the alphabet.  If I do have to repeat a known letter from a previous word, I try to choose a word that allows me to test a different position in the word for that known letter.  My fourth guess is focused on getting the known letters into the correct positions (unless I have already gotten them with my first 3 guesses), and if I don't get it right on the 4th guess, I have so far succeeded on the fifth.  I am reminded of the 3 bats (Bewitched, Bothered and Bemildred) in the Pogo cartoon strip - pollsters they were - who were always testing their questions on each other and reporting their success as "100 per cent of those sampled ...".  My win-lose statistics might be different in a few months....

your answer works fine for a purely random guessing machine algo. But if knowing that some certain vowels are confirmed,  a human will have greater confidence on a certain set of words. This means that P(those words | some vowels are correct) > P(other words | ...). Human knowledge in linguistics constrained that some combinations are more likely to happen.

Maybe I'm getting greedy here, but I'd love to see how this approach changes (or doesn't) on hard mode. Getting locked in to using yellow and green letters significantly limits opportunities to gather information in subsequent guesses. Given that the solution most often is a combination of high probability letters and medium or low probability letters, would it makes sense to start with a guess of medium probability letters only (like CHUMP). The hypothesis being you can collect data on down-ballot or second guess letters before being locked in to say using an A and ending with a T. That is to say, you accept a higher probability of all gray boxes with the hopes that eliminating letters allows you to solve the puzzle in few guesses. In the event you do get a green or yellow on a guess like CHUMP, you've narrowed the list of possible solutions further than a match from the guess SALET.

QUESTION, @3Blue1Brown : Could you come up with an algorithm/program that factors in which letter has the highest probability of being in a given spot (rather than just the overall frequency in five-letter words)?

I wonder if it would help with identifying which guess will "truly" come closest to splitting the pool down the middle. More interesting to me, however, is using it for prioritization. That is, could you prioritize guess options based on which letters are mostly likely to be each of the five spots? For example, I imagine that if you look at all five-letter words, certain letters (such as E, D, and S) would be slightly more likely to occupy the last spot; same with the second spot (which I'd guess would slightly favor letters such as T, L, and R).

I realize this is somewhat tangential to the primary "bit breakdown" point of your original videos. But I must admit that I REALLY want to know if my instincts are way off base or if looking at individual letter placement probabilities would be as beneficial as I imagine it would be. I certainly don't have the skills to do it myself, and I don't know to whom else to turn. So, please help me 3Blue1Brown; you're my only hope!

I was also one of the many that wrote up a script to spit out the best Wordle opening according to Wordle's daily answer list and they were: 'oater', 'orate' and 'roate'.
I simply created a list of letters that shows the number of occurrences (non-repeating) from the Wordle's daily answer list, It was not as complicated as 3Blue1Brown's method, since the entire script was only 6 lines.

Things to consider when using the opening mentioned above:
- You will never solve Wordle in 1 try, because none of them are in the answer list.
- It doesn't account for the best position of hitting a green letter
- It only provides the highest probability of eliminating the most possible letters (yellow and green) in the first guess.

I feel like your algorithms, no matter how complex, can't compete with the human brain's ability to improvise a pathway.

Like whether we decide to use a second guess that includes a yellow letter that's already known, or whether we make a word with 5 all new and unused letters to gain more info on what is/isn't in the word. (Which I have done before, and works well if you do it at the right time.)

Say the word is Shark but all we have is "shar"

Would it be better to guess "sharp" then "shard" then finally "shark"

Or should we just guess "pikes" and now know only after one extra guess that k is in the word despite 'p, i, and e' not being in the word.

The pikes pathway only took 2 extra guesses even though I knew the answer wouldn't be pikes. But it was assuredly going to take one less guess than worst case scenario of guessing "shar" words.

Funnily enough, I did a much simpler "best start" analysis, and I still get CRANE, plus one other! -
1. Take the 2715 possible winning words
2. For each letter position, measure the frequency of each alphabet letter - for example, "a" appears as the first letter in 141 or those words.
3. Give each letter a rank score for each position - for example, "a" is the 6th most common 1st letter, so "a" gets a "Position 1 Rank Score" of 21 points (26-6+1)
4. For each possible word, sum the position rank score of each of it's 5 letters.
5. Guess what the winner is? It's still CRANE!!! - c=25, R=24, A=26, N=25, E=26 (total=126)
6. Actually I lied: CRANE and SAINT tie for the best score of 126.
7. Runners-up are BRINE, CEASE, COAST and CRONE which all score 124
8. Assuming you get little-to-nothing from the first word, second good words (same method, with no repeated letters anywhere in the word) are:
CRANE, followed by FOIST
SAINT, followed by BOULE or CRUEL

Your mistake is the big assumption that the words picked for the solution are ones statistically more common than others in a random bit of text, or all the texts. But humans pick the answer and they will not go for the most statistically common words. RSTLN still makes the most sense with vowels a,e.  You need to ask what are the most common letters, not words, since you have no data on what criteria wordle makers use.

Hey, I do not know about your algorithm but I also wanted to make a few hypothesis that you should be knowing, I think your model might’ve generalised it but it’s the five letter vowel repeating pattern. There is a high probability for vowel following pattern like if the second letter is a vowel then there’s a high likelihood that the last letter is also a vowel and a considerable probability that the third letter is also a vowel. If the first letter is a vowel  then there’s a high likelihood of the fourth letter being a vowel. I think soare as an opener does the job, as not getting any hits is information itself so you use a combination of the remaining vowels with the matched or remaining unknown consonants most widely used ones being N,L,M,P. However instead of using a much exhaustive statistical approach you can use an instance based learner say K-NN and categorize the words into classes of vowel patterns eventhough they are of unequal frequency and then get the class of the word, and then maybe perform an optimal search in that pattern bucket.

Nice video! The considerations for SOARE, SLANE, SALET, CRANE et cetera are all related to the specific Wordle subset, which as you say at the end is now at the arbitrary whim of the New York Times, who indeed culled twenty-five words from the game shortly after acquiring it. If you revisit Wordle for a future video you should check out Laurent Poirrier and Mark Fisher who have found decision trees that explore the entire 12,972 wordlist in decision trees of depth 5. (Poirrier charmingly describes the process of honing trees specifically for the Wordle subset of 2,315 words as “cheat mode”.) Poirrier’s tree uses the root SPAER, while Fisher’s uses LARNT as a starter. Poirrier has rerun his work following the NYT reducing the set to 12,947 words, which resulted in a new root word for the smaller set, SABER.

I think one of the last points made here is the most important, that humans playing the game realistically won't be able to memorize the immense chain of best subsequent words for every possible response to each word played. Therefore, we need to rely on our own personal intuitions and vocabularies, which is likely to lead to different 'best' strategies and openers for different people. For instance, I find it much easier to guess the word when I know most of the consonants, and can then just fill in the vowels. There are fewer vowels than consonants, and therefore fewer possible options to guess from, e.g." _ O U _ _" is much less helpful than "C _ _ G H". So, I start with a 1-vowel (E) word, and often spend the first couple of turns focusing mostly on trying to eliminate or confirm common consonants (while also eliminating a few common vowels). This maybe isn't the strategy an AI would use, but it works best for how my brain works.

I love this video, but I'm not sure if you have defined an "optimal result" in the Wordle. Yes, it is nice to guess the word in as few tries as possible. But more important is to ALWAYS be able to solve it in 6 guesses. CRANE, or SALET, or TRACE may get you the answer is 3.4 guesses *on average*, but what is the probability of running out of guesses entirely? I personally use ADIEU as my opener (an idea I independently had before it went wild on Twitter), and even though I know it's nearly impossible for me to get the word on the 2nd guess, I also have never lost and seem to be perfectly set up for a 4th-guess win.

As someone who also wrote some quick software to solve Wordle, I REALLY enjoyed this video. My system also relied on generating a relative score for each word based on letter frequency, however I built it on a word list of roughly 4300 English words. I was pleased to see someone else had the issue of how to treat duplicate letters, as that was a source of immense complication for me. In my testing I found two other things. In terms of informational value, yellow is the most valuable guess, but second to that is grey, not green. As such I’ve started deliberately guessing letters which are not the least likely (z,x,q) but letters that are somewhat likely (p,d,h), in hopes that I get a gray or maybe a yellow. This method of eliminating letters is crucial if you play Wordle on hard mode, and helps stop the gears, tears, fears, pears, nears, trap that can make people (and even software) lose. That being said, there was a study out of Cambridge which points out that humans see words as whole entities rather than individual letters. Words are recognized by a first and last letter, but the letters inbetween can be completely jumbled. Therefore if you want to maximize your ability to think of answers it might be valuable to guess the most likely first and last letters, but to guess somewhat unlikely letters in the middle. Anyhow, I thought your video was excellent, and if anything I find the information theory makes Wordle all that much more fun.

With knowledge of the answer list (2315 words), and the "wrong answer" list (10657 words), I took a slightly different approach to finding the best starting word and came up with this list:


roate 61
raile 62
raise 62
soare 63
arise 64
irate 64
orate 64
ariel 66
arose 67



We have a long list of possible answers and after the first guess we are able to cross words off the list based on the clues given about the letters (exact match, found in the word someplace, not found in the word, etc.)


My definition for the best first guess:

"A word that will allow me (on average) to cross off more words from the answer list than any others, leaving me with a smaller list of words (on average) going forward."


For each possible first guess, I went through each possible answer, and calculated how many words could be crossed off for each. I then averaged the results and subtracted from 2315.


The numbers in my table represent the average number of words not crossed off the list over the entire range of possible answers (2315).

I pulled up a list of about 5700 common 5 letter words and checked which letters appear most commonly in which position. The letter S is most common in a 5 letter word list which includes grammatical forms because it appears as a plural for 4 letter nouns and as 3rd person singular for four letter verbs and therefore most s appear at the end. E is most common in 4th position, A is most common in 2nd and R most common in 3rd. A human player  benefits most from getting green tiles as soon as possible. “CARES” gives you the best chance for an early green hit as well as using a selection of very commonly used letters.

I did my own pencil and paper analysis based on number frequency and weighted placement data before ever seeing your first video and concluded that TRACE then LOINS then potentially followed by DUMPY is the best opening sequence for gaining raw, non-repeating information. I was so happy to see the computer came up with the same opener!! After the first video, I thought, “CRANE is cool, but I’m going to stick with TRACE,” and it turns out I was right!

A more human efficient algorithm would probably include guesses that gives information on common letter combinations - I.E. if the word has an I and a G then I can reasonably guess it's likely an ING word.

Caulk (a recent word) was a good example - After my first two guesses I knew where the A was and that there was an L in the word - I also knew there was no E in the word and no S. Because of the A location and no E in the word I knew it was likely the third letter was a U (AUL is a common grouping that still had letters available to go behind it (D, K, Y), without an S or an E - AIL doesn't have a final letter behind it (AILE, AILS)

When I saw your first video in my reccomended seeing crane, I intentionally didnt watch the video. It wasnt just spoilers for the game though, it's that as a player the optimal strategies are entirely different, I gain more value from the position of the final letter for example, as it defines the sound and hence rhyming words. I consider consonant pairs like l and t and r and n because 5 letter words generally have these pairings to match a small number of vowels. The best opener isnt the most greens and yellows but more complex. I know plurals arent used much so I dont use s too early. Anyway, I was happy to see this video with the mistake and the further analysis. I liked your final conclusions, I agree. I find it interesting how my friends will play though, I have seen Soare and Clint as openers now, and I never use yhem but I still often get it in 3 guesses. Thanks for the lesson!

While looking at the last example at 10:15 with AUDIO and SPOUT, an idea came to my mind: When you know that I is in the right position, would it actually be better to not have an I in your second guess, to get more information out of that 4th position? Like if you put an N into the 4th position, it would have been yellow and you would have got the information that it is somewhere used in the correct answer. When you just stick to that I, you would not get any more information out of that 4th position in your 2nd guess. If that holds true, it would mean that the whole process of only testing "possible" combinations in the 2nd (3rd, ...) guess would not be the best algorithm if you want to calculate the best opening (and maybe 2nd, 3rd, ...) guess.

The key to successfully solving the game every time is trying to put in as many letters as we can... So if we know a letter's exact position, DO NOT use that letter again in another guess and use different letters almost every time. Using this method, it is difficult to get it in 3rd or 4th try but it guarantees you to give the right word, at least in the last guess

Great set of videos!  As a solver, my personal approach was to find two words that had all the vowels, plus r, s and t as a pair of openers.  The problem here, of course, is if you use the pair, you have a lot of information, when weighted towards common letters, but you give up most of the opportunity to get a Wordle in 3 guesses.  So, my first set - and there are a couple of others  that work as well - are outer + fails.

I think the optimal human-executable opening strategy would contain more instructions than just the first guess. As you explained, it's impossible to memorize 240-ish different 2nd guesses depending on the first pattern. For me, an optimal opening strategy would contain a single guess for the first word, and then depending on the presence/absence result of a single letter (like, "there's at least 1 e in the answer" vs "no e in the answer") you'd have 2 different words for the 2nd guess.
To solve that, you'd need to brute-force (at the same time):
What's that first guess?
Which of the 5 (or possibly 4) letters do you base your rule for the second word on?
What's the 2nd guess if that letter is present?
What's the 2nd guess if that letter is absent?
And for the remaining guesses (3rd++) you'd probably need to assume that the human (now left without guidance) plays a "greedy" strategy that maximizes the information gained based on the word frequency. Since again, nobody could remember the full list of Wordle solutions. And also assuming that a human plays the guess that results in optimal information gain for the one move is already a stretch; so assuming that they could think 2 steps ahead is beyond unrealistic.

In the initial explanation there is one case missing: what happens when the first "E" misses, but the second one is actually right? Let's say you put two E's, and the second one is in the right position. Following previous rules, one could expect the first E comes yellow signifiing there is an E but not there, and the other one gray signifying there are no more E's.
However, this feels like it would be confusing for the user. A more sensible resolution would be to pain the first E gray and the second one green, even if this is not fully coherent with the behavior for when the E does not match that letter.

Commented on the last video but you also have a bug when accounting for different word frequencies. You should be maximizing expected information gain in word distribution, not maximizing entropy of the word’s resulting color patterns. You can see the mistake when you report the sequence of word entropies; the difference isn’t equal to the entropy on the right-hand side, as it is in the uniform-word-distribution case.

Plus, it is always good to start with one of the more common patterns of vowel placements so you are likely to get GREEN results, which of course includes putting an E in the last position and another, different vowel in the middle position. So if I start with "LANCE" and get no hits, I might try something like "SPORT" next. It has been extremely common to guess by a process of elimination by the third or sometimes fourth guess.

Of course, taking this approach requires that you think long and hard to find a possible answer given the clues so far -- you know the right answer has to be a very common word. And that can be challenging, since it's not how our brains like to work. Whenever you find it very hard to think of any word that might fit the clues so far, then you just need to keep trying to think of one until you come up with it and then that will be your next guess, and most of the time, it will be the answer. You know the answer exists, so don't make another guess until you figure out what it is by exhaustively imagining every possible combination with the remaining letters.

If one or more letters turns green, and there are still too many possibilities to guess the answer, then I will omit those if possible from the next guess so as to maximize the information I can gain. But if there are yellow letters, then I will usually try to reuse them in different (and likely) positions in hopes of getting some of them to go green.

Even at the third guess, if I still have not narrowed it down and can still think of at least 3 possible common-word answers, then I will try to come up with a guess that maximizes the candidate extra letters that can form possible and likely answers, even though this necessarily means that this next guess cannot possibly be the answer. Then I can be sure to find the answer in only 2 more turns instead of wasting 3 or 4 by swapping out a single letter repeatedly in an effort to guess the right answer.

Using these techniques, I got my stats for 200 games down to the following:
1 guess: 0 times
2 guess: 4 times
3 guess: 68 times
4 guess: 81 times
5 guess: 42 times
6 guess: 4 times
LOST: 1 time (that was early in the sequence, before I got the hang of it)

But every single variant I've found of this game (on web sites) messes up the replicated letter in a guess, and they ALWAYS show out-of-place letters that are in the target as YELLOW, even after all the actual such letters in the target have been accounted for in the guess. So if the answer has only 1 E but the guess has 2 E's, they always show both E's as yellow or maybe one is green. Very misleading! So the "bug" mentioned here is actually how every single wordle game I've ever played has done its scoring. And yes, it is OBVIOUSLY a bug!

The intuition part mentioned at the end of the video is a major thing that often gets lost when it comes to math and computer algorithms. My openers are sonic and ultra. Notably there is no "e" in these openers even though its the most common letter. The reason I have for this is that I can usually go on intuition and figure out whether or not my word will have an e in it based on the other 4 vowels. If I get only an a vowel, well there are few 5 letter words that only have an a and if the puzzle is obviously not one of them then the puzzle must have an e or y with e being the much more likely situation. Likewise if I have an a and o, very few 5 letter words have an a, o and e and I can rule out e as a probability.

This results in me being able to get an extra letter of information from my first 2 guesses. While a computer could be programmed to account for such a thing it requires foresight of such a possible solution and more computing power. Mind you I'm not saying mine is optimal, but it does open the door for me to have more information than the algorithm might come up with.

This leaves only the possibility of repeated letters or the more rarely used letters w, k, j, x, q, z

Tips for after guess 4:
- 5 letters revealed: should be easy enough
- 4 letters revealed: one letter is likely repeated (keep in mind the average 5 letter word has three consonants and two vowels, so think about which is likely needed)
-3 letters revealed: likely to use a w (especially if an h is revealed) or possibly a k (especially if an n is revealed) usually has at least one letter repeating
-2 letters revealed: there are very few words that can be created with the guidelines given. The only example I can think of is ‘kayak’ if only ‘a’ and ‘y’ are revealed.
-1 letter revealed: not possible

Using ALIEN (the three vowels are three of the four most frequent letters, N is 7th, L is 9th), followed by TOURS. Not that there's a massive number of people that think this "ruins the game" but I think it's cool to look at this kind of stuff. Personally, I try to change my word every day. I specifically avoid words that are known to be very good, like Audio, Adieu, but oftentimes my words will include 2-3 vowels, and some combination of C, S, T, R, L, N, and other common consonants. It's fun to mix it up, while still trying to play somewhat optimally. Just like you said, this is about learning information theory (fantastically done, by the way) more than just trying to solve the game.

In trying to make the game a little more difficult, it's tempting to try and use words heavy on consonants (Think CLAMP) however it makes it really hard to get guesses in three tries, as you often won't get enough vowels to be able to confidently guess the word, assuming you even hit the letters you need to start making guesses at that point. As he said in the first video, getting the word in 4 tries is par, and 3 is generally considered good.

That being said, I think this is fascinating because for the average player who isn't using a computer, there's still so much knowledge to gain from this. It makes sense now to me - Wordle isn't about what information you get from the yellow and the green, it's also about the information you get from the gray. Synthesizing both sides of information helps you make smart plays.

I wrote a solver which works by trying to choose the optimal guess from the set, that is it looks at the frequency of each letter in each column, scores them based on that, then choses the highest scoring word from the remaining list (assuming hard mode). It doesnt try to brute force the solution as you do, but rather come up with the next optimal guess as a human (with perfect knowledge) would.

The initial guesses it comes up with are
CARES: Full list of valid guesses;
SLATE: restricting to the list of words to the "valid answers" list

Interestingly my inital program looked at the frequency of the letter in each word rather than the column top answer: SOARE (or AROSE as I prefered to use as they had the same score) for the full word list, LATER if restricting to only valid answers.

One thing I'm curious about is, in the first video, 3b1b talks about bits of information and all that, and says that if a letter in a certain color gives you 3 bits and another letter gives you 2 bits, then you have 5 bits of information. Are we sure that is always the case? Or if that is the case here? Because I feel like it shouldn't. The way I see it, some of the information that a letter is giving you could also be, at the same time, be given by the other letter; and the bits of information would overlap, just like when you sum things from two sets that have an overlap and you have to account for it to not count the overlap twice. For example, suppose a dictionary where there were an unusually large amount of words that start with GR and words that start with DL. If you use an opener word that starts with GR, for example, wouldn't the R´s color give you less information that it should? For example, if both G and R are green, the G it´s giving you the full 3 bits of information, but before you look at the R´s color, you already now the R is already more likely to be green, because the G was green. So, if a green R in second place it´s 2 bits of information by itself, maybe a green R AFTER a green G only gives you 1 bit of information. This would work the same if both G and R were grey, or if we had used D and L. So, for this reason, wouldn´t the best opener start with either GL or DR, taking bits of information from both different groups of likely words, and trying to minimize the overlap between the bits of information to get closer to their sum?

Of course, none of this matters after brute-forcing it several steps, everything is taken into consideration that way, but I would still love it if someone could ellucidate here and help me understand. Thx for reading if you made it here :)

Like most analyses of wordle, I think something important has been missed.  The goal in this discussion is to minimize the number of guesses on average needed.  I believe the "correct" goal should be to maximize the probability of winning.  This is the usual goal in game theory.  In the first video it was mentioned briefly that optimal play led to 1.16 bits of uncertainty after 2 guesses.  Presumably this means optimal play will always win in at most 4 guesses.  However, this is only for the wordle list of words.    What strategy is optimal for guaranteeing  a win?   Can we guarantee a win in 4 guesses?

I have no idea if this has any merit in your algorithm, but I read some "tips" in an interview w/ the creator about how he chooses his words. Specifically, 1) there are no plurals and 2) if there is more than one possibility given the guess (for instance "SH??D"), he picks the least common option.

If you search for Alex Selby wordle, you'll come across a guy that used exhaustive search to figure out the mathematically optimal strategy. He came to the same conclusion that SALET is the optimal first guess. He also came up with a neat way to present the 'strategy' in a text file (guess SALET, if you get this pattern of green/yellow/gray then guess this word next, and so on until you win).

His source code is available online and you can do all sort of stuff with it like computing the optimal strategy for your favorite first guess or changing the underlying word list. It's two different approaches to get to the same solution: 3b1b is from the teacher's perspective, using the game as an excuse to teach you about information theory whereas Alex Selby's is from the computer enthusiast perspective finding a brute force algorithm and optimizing it just enough to be able to crunch the numbers in a reasonable amount of time. It reminds me of the 'Alice vs Bob' 3b1b video of solving problems from a different perspective from not too long ago.

If my first guess (five very common letters) hits lightly (three or four grays), is it better to focus on the letters that hit or try a second guess with five common letters not in my initial guess?

SALET turns out to be the best choice word for Hard Mode if you want to minimize the expected number of turns it takes to get the answer; It also can be used to maximize the probability of getting the correct answer in three or fewer guesses, with the added condition that you want to always win in six guesses or less (that is, you don't lose.) SALET also maximizes your chances of winning in two turns, again under the condition that there are no losses.

But SALET does not maximize the chances of winning in five or fewer turns . You can actually win in five or fewer words 100% of the time if you start with CARLS, but this lowers the expected number of turns.

You can maximize your chance of getting the correct answer in four turns or less starting with LEAST, an anagram of SALET.

There are two joys in solving a puzzle: The first is finding the solution; the second is exploring the process. Applying information theory to the process is a joy in itself, and for some a joy greater than finding an answer. Similar feats are done that result in Rubik’s cubes being solved by robots, or machines that can sink a basketball from anywhere on the half court. The mechanics of invention are not finding a solution, but in finding a new puzzle in the process that leads to a better solution. Farming is advanced not by figuring out how to make it rain or have longer days to work, but on solving problems of yield and disease. Transportation is advanced not by breading better horses, but making cars, trucks, and airplanes. This is true out-of-the-box thinking, looking at the problem with eyes that are larger or smaller than the problem in its original form requires. There is a joy here that needs no apology, because the exercise is in its own right a challenge to be met and the consequences of such exploration may yield innovations with far greater benefits than knowing the answer to today’s Wordle.

If I didn't make any mistakes in my Python script, playing the game randomly (i.e., with a random starting word, and random guesses among all remaining possible answers in each round) wins somewhere around 85% of the time. As such, for an added challenge, I play Wordle to lose--i.e., use all information, but guess wrong six times in a row.
It would probably be pretty simple to write a good losing algorithm, but for a human, it's hard! So far, I've successfully lost 7 of 25 games played, and 6 of those 7 required getting lucky guessing combinations of letters I thought might be words.

As I mentioned in the first video... if you're going to write an algorithm with the word bank for the best possible way to solve... you really should include a history function.

You're current algorithm lets you know the best opener for the first game of wordle, but if you remove each 'correct' answer from the bank after each puzzle, the bank gets smaller. The possibilities get fewer. The code has to adapt and choose a new best opener.

I realize that coding-wise, this is rather difficult to do(depending on language probably...), as it is essentially running an entirely new iteration of the code (minus one word) after each solve. With the word bank being in order and not a 'random' choice... I feel like that would make it a smidge easier... but not much.

However... I'm just really curious as to see how many different best first guesses you end up with, and which word has the longest run-streak.

I got very similar results with a quick and dirty method of assigning a guess two points for each letter in the correct place and one point for each letter in the answer but not in the correct place. I iterated over all first guesses against all answers, and then iterated again for second guesses, which were not allowed to have any letters in common with the first guess, for the top 250 scoring first guesses. Using this method, the best first two guesses were "soare" and then "clint", but I prefer going with the 5th best pairing from because the words are more common: "slate" and then "irony". Starting with these, I almost always get to the word within 4 guesses, and often in 3. But looking at some of my top results, a lot of the same "rare" words show up: soare, stane, carte, urate, prate, raile, salet...

I used slightly different. less educated approach but seem to have similiar results.
1. Take a list of ~130k English words (you can find it on github)
2. Reduce it to 5-letter words (~15k left)
3. Make a freuqency table for them (in your first video, you proposed a frequency table for all words, which is different than for 5-letter words!)
4. Calculate score for each of the words and pick highest
5. Input feedback from wordle
6. Reduce list of words
7. Repeat steps 4-6
(There are some caveats)

soare also shows up as the best word if you optimize the degree of how well a single guess can bisect the possibility space of solutions. So basically, if you take the best letters at the best position and quantify their strength by their ability to reduce the list of all possible words, no matter if the hint is green, yellow, or grey, you also get soare as top choice.

Best thing about this is that this method is blazingly fast, you can analyze all 13k words in just a second or two, and any subsequent guesses can be calculated in real time

As somebody who doesn't play Wordle, yes, I very much appreciate the quick lecture on information theory.

Alternative approach: using a corpus of common 5-letter words, I calculated a frequency for each letter/position combination. This yielded these Top3 letters for each position within a word: [1]={a,e,o}, [2]={a,r,o}, [3]={i,a,r}, [4]={e,i,a}, [5]={s,e,a}. Then, my goal was to find 2-3 words that would quickly exhaust most probable letters while placing them in their most probable positions. Deliberately avoiding words containing extremely common vowels 'A' and 'I' and any duplicate letters, I scored them based on the frequency rank of the letters in their respective positions. (The reason for omitting 'AI' is that due to their frequency I rather try to prove their absence.) The best word that came out was "orles", but I opted for less obscure and easier to remember "CORES". Removing these letters from candidate words, the second word is "BUNTY". If necessary, the third word would be "PLAID", finally trying the remaining vowels 'AI'. At this moment, all vowels and most common consonants are exhausted, which leaves reasonably small subset of (often mutually incompatible) consonants. This way I almost never needed more than 4 attempts.

Thanks for these videos, I really liked digging deep (for me) into the algorithm you developed.

Unfortunately I choose to play the 'hard' version, or rather a harder than 'hard' version, which is to force myself to use all of the information I have in my next guess, i.e. I cannot have a guess that I know is not the correct answer.
If a letter comes up green then that letter has to be in that position on my next guess, if it comes up yellow then I cannot use that letter in the same position in any of the following guesses and I have to have it (in a different position) in future guesses. If I have a grey letter I cannot use that letter again in any future guesses.
As you can imagine this would require a complete rework of your algorithm.

As a personal choice I only 'guess' (is it a guess when we make a choice given information?) what I consider to be real words. This had its drawback when I discovered that Wordle, a game developed by a Briton and hosted (then) on a UK server, used US spelling. I got really stumped on a word until I came to that disappointing realisation.

After watching this video, I spent some time doing my own analysis with an emphasis on HUMAN play as opposed to computer play. Obviously there is a computer optimal word, but that's assuming a computer will be making the next guesses with a knowledge of the wordlist. It also only gives us a first guess, instead of a pair of guesses, and yet most games require at least two before solving can really begin.

So I ran an evaluation on every possible PAIR of words to see which ones give us the most human usable information on average (green hits are 1 point, yellow hits are 1/(nongreen spaces-1) points). While "SOARE" is the best SINGLE starting word, it turns out that the best PAIR of words is "CRATE" followed by "SOILY". The second best is "CRANE" followed by "SOILY". lol

Funny enough though, "SOARE" followed by "CLINT" is only 6th in the list, so it's still a fantastic pair of words to work with for human play.

Another funny thing that appeared in the data is how many of the good pairs included words with a double "E" at the end. Apparently it's almost worth doing a double "E" just to find out where the "E" is, if any.

S is the most used '1st letter' in the answers list (366 times). E is the most used 5th letter (424). The 2nd, 3rd, and 4th are A (304), A (307), and E (318), respectively.
Now that doesn't make a word. So to find the word, I gave each word in the answer list, a 'word score', based on each letters 'used' count, per position.
Out of all the words used in the answer list, the highest score is SLATE (1437).
1. SLATE (1437)
2. SAUCE (1411)
3. SLICE (1409)
4. SHALE (1403)
5. SAUTE (1398)
6. SHARE (1393)
7. SOOTY (1392)
8. SHINE (1382)
9. SUITE (1381)
10. CRANE (1378)
Yep, CRANE is just in the list..., and is the first word that finally uses a different 1st letter other than S. And btw at 7th, SOOTY is the first word to use a different 5th letter other than E.
Now, we can go one (or 2) steps further than this for a 2nd (and 3rd word) score, based on the 1st word, eliminating all 5 letters used in that word (or 4 in the case of SOOTY).
For SLATE as the first word, eliminating S ,L ,A ,T , and E, the highest 2nd word score is CRONY (1255), with BRINY a close 2nd (1252). Btw, Y is used as the best, 5th position letter, in the top 10 of 2nd words. The top 10 2nd word list number scores is CRONY (1255), BRINY (1252), CORNY (1186), IRONY (1091), PRIVY (1085), BOOBY (1084), BOOZY (1080), GRIMY (1080), PHONY(1076), GOODY (1071), MOODY (1063), CURRY (1063).
If we then eliminate all letters in both the 1st and 2nd word, for a 3rd word score search. For SLATE/CRONY, the highest 3rd word score is HUMID (592), giving a total score of 3284. For SLATE/BRINY, the highest 3rd word score is POOCH (956), followed by COUCH (933), and POUCH (877), giving total scores of, 3645, 3622, and 3566, respectively.
As you can see, the SLATE/BRINY/? combo beats the SLATE/CRONY/? combo, pretty comprehensively.
I still haven't completely all the calcs for the absolute optimal 3 word combo. But SLATE/BRINY/POUCH is the 3 word combo I'm using atm.
I use POUCH for the 3rd word because it uses 5 distinct letters, instead of 4 with POOCH, as it uses all 5 vowels, which should help your odds of working out the word for your forth guess.
Either way, SLATE/BRINY is the top 2 word score for a 1st and 2nd word.

NOTE : I posted this to Don's pinned post, but have added it here for possible more visibility.
Cheers

It’s interesting that you’re looking for the optimal word.  I play a lot of scrabble, and knowing which scrabble letters are higher scoring because they are less common, I would never start out with a word with any scrabble point higher than a 1.  I use the word “rates” and then “hound” and very often (greater than 50% of the time) I am able to solve the puzzle on the third try based on the info I get from those two words.  Because an elimination is almost as good as a right guess, all I need to do is look through the remaining letters that I haven’t tested and see if anything pops out at me, and very often it does.   I find Wordle to be a fun game because it relies on logic as much as good guesses.  It drives me crazy when I see people posting their results, and when they find a letter in the right spot they keep trying using that same letter in subsequent guesses, because that doesn’t give them any new information.  Once I know a letter is in the right spot, I don’t need to keep entering it there on subsequent guesses.  I need to figure out what the other letters are.  A scrabble habit is very helpful in this game.

On the linguistics side of things, as an educator yourself, you really ought to know better than to fall into the prescriptivist pitfall of the notion of something being a "real word". All a word is is a set of connected morphemes with a complete and independent meaning. Something either is a word or it isn't. You don't need to know every word in the language for them all to be words.

But also, my approach to an optimal solution is different, because the statistical approach still leaves a fair number of edge-cases where the 6 guesses run out. My approach is, instead to choose words that have the smallest maximum possible number of remaining answers after it. At the same time, though, I exclusively use words in Wordle's answer list, because, to me, it feels unreasonable to let the player guess a word that can't be the answer. I also play on Hard Mode (with additional rules that all clues must be used, including clues of absent letters and of incorrect letter placement).

I realized how to incorporate a new strategy from watching your first Wordle video. It hadn’t occurred to me to NOT use the correct letter from my first guess in my second guess until I watched your video. Watching the video, I first thought, “that’s not how human players can make use of information”, but then I realized I CAN use that strategy on a smaller scale. For example, if I get few green squares and no yellow squares in the first guess, it makes sense to use all new letters in the second guess (i.e don’t bother using the one or two green letters I got in my first guess). If I think I have a chance of correctly guessing on my second guess then I want to repeat all green letters in the correct locations, but if I don’t think it’s likely I’ll win in 2 guesses then repeating the green squares gives me no new information. I can go back to including all the green squares on my third guess. I might treat yellow squares differently because  I might want to figure out the correct location for those.

I understand that you are trying to exemplify information theory in the case of playing Wordle.
But a human plays the game with a brain and seems to do it quite differently to the way computer is programmed using info theory. Given that any 5 letter word has an equal chance of being selected as the target word there is no optimal first guess. It is a guess after all. The logical processing comes after the first guess has letters identified as present or in the correct position. Starting with the guess "crane" the "a" was identified as being in the correct position. The next choice of possible word MUST have an "a" that position. In the example the next choice changed the "a" to something else. This getting further away from the correct answer.

Not to brag, but I am 17 for 17 in solving the daily puzzle, with no failures. (Ok, I admit I'm bragging a bit).  My results histogram shows that I'm about evenly split between 3 and 4 tries-to-success, with a few outliers at 5 and 2 guesses.  Given that my strategy is to discover the possible appearance of all five vowels and the letter "Y" in the first two guesses (if possible), and without regard to where any given vowel is in the guess, it doesn't surprise me that the words SOARE, CRANE, and ADIEU, would be optimal first-word guesses.  So my question is:  is it true that such a vowel-heavy word optimizing technique would always yield more information early in the game that would help later in the game than would any other strategy?  In other words, given that the ratio of vowels to all letters in a 5-letter word is expectedly relatively high (at least 20%), wouldn't it always be a better strategy to find all of the vowels early in the game?  My intuition, based on my partial understanding of your analysis, tells me that my strategy is not necessarily the best one, but it's not clear to me why that may be the case.  Thanks for an excellent analysis!

I think as a human player the optimal start is actually the word laser, this tests e with multiple letters e is often paired with, strong chance to identify two vowels also. If you only draw one vowel it is likely there is still another vowel and the word count, seems to cover a large proportion of the remaining.

From this information you will have covered 4 vowels and 6 extremely common consonants, if you're still missing a vowel it's either i or a double up of the vowel you already have, the third guess allows you to eliminate the final vowel aswell as confirm some positions and test a few more, if you're still missing lots of consonants a word like weigh could slide in.

Imagine a version of Wordle that didn't allow you to type any word information that the information you've already gleaned disagrees with?  So if you got a grey square on a Z in your starting guess for instance, you wouldn't then be able to type a Z in any future guesses. This would introduce more possible losing scenarios than merely running out of guesses-allowed - you could also run out of guesses-possible.  Wonder how that would skew things?

There's also a bit of extra information that you can get from the on-screen keyboard distinct from the colored letters. Say there's 2 e's in the correct answer, and you guess a single e in one of the correct locations. The letter in your guess will turn green (letting you know you got that spot correct), but the e on the keyboard will turn yellow, letting you know that there's a second e! I don't know if that's particularly useful, but it is extra information, so there's that.

What about a completely different approach: concentrate on the consonants. The possible combination of 2 consonants are quite limited in the english language. A lot of combinations can not even be pronounced. So by knowing one of them guessing the neighbour is easier since a lot of letters are very unlikely to be the neighbour even if they are still in the game. On the other hand the information in a vowel is not worth very much, because vowels are so limited in number. They can easily be tried out/guessed compared to trying to fit any of the remaining consonants in the remaining open slots. You often can read/understand words without all the vwls bng prsnt or replaced by other sounds like in some kids songs.

SLATE 3.4056 is better than SALET 3.4164. You are missing that the goal is minimum score not maximum entropy. When down to 2 words always pick the first thus a score of 1.5. If 3 words and one of these creates 3 unique states then pick this word thus score = 2-1/3=1.667. When have N words that can be separated by one of these N then the score is 2-1/N which is better than using a 12972 word with a best score of 2.

For me the weighting of vowels versus consonants is wrong. I reckon that guessing the correct word is easier if you have lots of Green or Yellow consonants. So I only put one vowel in my first word. In a standard 5 letter word you could suspect that there are three consonants and two vowels. And if you know the consonants then the vowels are easier to figure out. But if you have a majority of vowels over consonants you're likely struggling to figure out the word.

I really, really wish you wouldn't say "the theoretically optimal first guess" several times at the beginning when it absolutely is not that. That is a serious mistake that is going to significantly confuse people.

It is even more egregious when a significant part of the video turns out to be describing the fact that it is a heuristic, not the theoretically optimal first guess, and how you calculated that heuristic.

Also, the problem this gets at - that you really need to search the entire decision tree to find the optimal first guess - is even more an issue for Hard Mode, where the guess that gives the most information might also have more possible scoring outcomes that significantly constrain which subsequent guesses you can make - potentially putting you into a position where your subsequent guesses are much less informative. I'm not even sure the "top 250" is a safe heuristic here because of that.

In my personal project for a guided solver, I noted down results and within not that many tries found a similar issue. My solver put letters with no hits on an ignore list, and then remove all the word candidates with that letter. Turns out that is bad with guesses with two of the same letter.

I think this is one of those cases where I thought it would be smart to optimize, but turned out I should have waited with trying to optimize until the logic was solid. :)

Here's what I think is the real "Wordle" take away. Look at the list of the top 15 @ 10:52. They range in expected information from 5.89 to 5.79. 0.1 bits different. Over a few dozen games, that isn't going to make a lick of difference. And I think that's why the game is fun. Lots and lots and lots of words have good enough entropy that knowing the "optimal" strategy doesn't really make your histogram stand out from your friends. We can all play and have a good time without feeling like we need to be in on some "secret opening that if I only knew I'd crush this game."

Edit: Oh, see I paused at 10:52 to write the above comment. And then you went and made the same observation even more explicit. Nice.

I use a strategy to cover the maximum letters possible so understand better which letters are present. For this I would use:

1) SOUTH
2) PLACE
3) BRINK
4) FUDGY

Depending on the number cumulative hits on each try, I decide to go to the next word. At 4 words, you cover 19 alphabets with only 'U' repeating in the 4th try. While this doesn't result in the fastest guess, it gives the best possibility of solving in 4-5 guesses. I'm sure people can come up more optimised words based on the likelihood of alphabets presence in the words.

My personal favorite opening is ADIEU. If I get all gray, I usually go PHONY second. If I get a yellow letter, I'll make sure my next word tries that letter in a different slot, and I'll always look for opportunities to test multiple possibilities in a single word, e.g. if I have it narrowed down to S_ASH I'll play something like SMELT rather than guess between SLASH/STASH/SMASH/SWASH. I feel like this sort of narrowing-down approach works best for the way people actually think about words, and I'm sure it's more or less what most people are doing.

Something worth looking into is the number of equivalence classes after a guess. If you were to guess randomly from the bucket of words on the first guess, your probability of guessing correctly would be 1 over the number of words in that bucket. However, the probability of that bucket being the one that actually occurs is the number of words in the bucket over 2315, which cancels out, so the probability of randomly guessing correctly on the second guess is 1 in the total number of nonempty buckets. If the game only allowed 2 guesses then the optimal first word would be "trace", which results in 150 nonempty buckets (one of which only has the word "trace" in it, so you would win on the first guess there). If you could come up with a strategy that leads to 2315 nonempty buckets, then you have a solution no matter what the word ends up being. In the worst case it's going to be at least 4 guesses deep.

This pair of videos, and their information theory standpoint, made me ask this question:

Given a game of the same rule set as Wordle, but an indefinite word length, what word length (for English) provides the greatest difficulty? Or a more technical phrasing: for what English word length does the average and/or optimal opening word provide the least quantity of information? (two slightly different but related definition options) EDIT: actually a better concrete question is given an optimal solving algorithm, what is the average number of needed answers, but I kind of like the other two options.

And for a bonus, how can you estimate this non-exhaustively (not performing the calculations in these videos for each word length). As words get longer, you have more options for duplicate letters and matching letter overlap. But too long, and the sheer amount of words of that length in the English language drastically drops off. How do these two factors balance against each other for different lengths? Intuition tells me somewhere around 7 to 10 letters, but maybe I'm wrong!

Question: if I’m understanding correctly, the method applied to determining best starting words seems to assume maximizing elimination is best.

But is this really the case with human intelligence? How about choosing words based on how common their letters are in the English language, and trying to confirm information rather than eliminate it? If you get lucky, confirming letters saves a step vs. eliminating them, because elimination only tells you what it *isn’t*, and then you still have to find what it might be.

I see at the end of this video you touched on this. I’d be really interested if there was some way to quantify how human intelligence actually plays Wordle (with an understanding of English word structure; knowing when certain letters are likely to follow others; etc.) vs. the robotic algorithmic approach inherent to information theory.

I could be wrong, and probably am, but I wonder if the true optimum (taking the sophistication of human intelligence into account) is actually a word that maximizes your odds of getting some correct letters initially, so you can form your next guess based on deeper knowledge of word structure.

My typical opening words as 2 lists, 1A - Audio 2A - Entry. Looking at the older list of letters ranked by frequency, ETA OIN SHR DLU in that order (As of old linotypes), the words "Audio Entry" contains every vowel, and the first 2 consonants. But even with this , it's possible get only 1 "bit" of information, a single yellow E. But that's my personal most optimal 2 words. However, I have a suboptimal (4 word)... So looking back at etaoin shrdlu, and remembering that PANGRAMS exist, I looked up 26-letter pangrams, and pangrams made of only 5 letter words, which should allow for, a maximun density of checking for letters. 5 letter words plucked from the pangram list are Judge, Quartz, Check, Brown, Waltz, Squid, and a few others, but as an example, 4 words in random order, Squid Check Brown Waltz. 20 letters, contains 18 unique letters, and all but 1 letter from ETAOINSHRDLU, Missing the H, And includes those 3 letters that tend to throw people off, W, Q, and Z. This means a few things. If you're playing in a way that is Naive of the list of possible words, you're maximizing letters checked, which means you can then take the letters that are identified, and the letters that you specifically haven't used, which is a very VERY Short list, you can more feasibly go over anagrams. Though it doesn't check the most common duplicates like a word with 2 E's, multiple S's, etc. But considering I can just dump in "SQUID CHECK BROWN WALTZ" really quickly and then just puzzle it out and still get the word almost 90% of the time...

It's not optimal for a computer, but it covers a lot of space which is good for human brains to pick out what fits.

Here's the logic I wrote for my re-make:

def makeGuess(guess):
g = list(guess)
a = list(word)
out = ["white", "white", "white", "white", "white"]
for i in range(5):
if g[i] == a[i]:
setKeyboardColor(g[i], "green")
g[i] = "_"
a[i] = "-"
out[i] = "green"
for i in range(5):
if g[i] in a:
setKeyboardColor(g[i], "green")
a[a.index(g[i])] = "-"
g[i] = "_"
out[i] = "yellow"
for i in "".join(g).replace("_", ""):
setKeyboardColor(i, "red")
return "".join([colored.fg(out[x]) + guess[x] for x in range(5)]) + colored.attr("reset"), out

Does this change if you start to look at COMBINING words though? What if, instead of trying to squeeze maximum entropy out of a word by computing how much I EXPECT from the next word, I instead go for two - or even three - words that TOGETHER have a very high expected entropy?

This is actually mostly valuable in dordle or quordle (where you guess 2 and 4 words at the same time respectively, having only one extra chance per extra word compared to regular wordle), but for example, my favored opener is THOSE + ANGRY + LUCID. While individually, these words may be worse, together they contain the 13 most common letters in the English language, by either text (G and Y fall lower in ranking) or dictionary (H and Y fall lower in the ranking) - and Y covers the last vowel. This allows me to directly pin down the correct word on the next guess in I'd say about 75-80% of cases, and the last two free slots are nearly always enough to get all four words in quordle, something that's almost impossible if you try to hunt down one word at a time.

I don't think analyzing a game ruins it. Mathematically analyzing a game and playing it to play it are totally different activities that I enjoy for different reasons. There's games that can't be analyzed to be perfectly solved, like your average real video game, and games that are much more interesting to analyze than play, like the games in Winning Ways For Your Mathematical Plays.

English is not my first language, so while I'm actually able to play Wordle because I understand the language just fine, it's harder for me to think of English words given some letters. So my strategy in Wordle is to search for as many letters as possible. Thus, I always start with 3 fixed words: IDEAL - STORM - PUNCH. In that way, I test all the 5 vowels and all (or almost all) the most used consonantes (D, L, S, T, R, M, P, N, C, H). So usually I don't win fast, but I win nonetheless. I've played all the 200+ Wordle games and lost only 10 so far.

my standard opener is SATES:
- E, T, A, S are all very common
- checks for two S
- checks for S in beginning and end spots, which shapes how other consonants can be placed
- checks for A and E in second and fourth spots, very common for two-syllable words (if those are the only two yellows I usually follow up with FERAL)

It's interesting that SOARE keeps showing up in your lists, because it's also the top word from a simpler and more arbitrary method by Bertrand Fan ("The Best Starting Word in WORDLE"). They just counted how many green and yellow tiles you get from each starting guess if you use that guess on the whole answer list, but gave greens twice as much weight as yellows.
